seat of a first-order administrative division

•Two proposals for institutional development are produced, negotiated with stakeholders and submitted to the competent administrative autorities(CAAs) concerning secure land tenure in Farfara and coordinated investment promotion in the New Assiut.
•Two institutional anchors for participatory planning and management of human settlements are created and/or strengthened.

comment.narrative:
1. GOPP and local partners in southern Egypt introduced to participatory approaches but yet to adopt them on regular basis with in-house capacity and enabling organizational set-ups.
2. Local partners unfamiliar with participatory planning, institutional barriers cause investment growth to slow down and put livelihoods at risk.
3. Coordination between investment policies and mechanisms in Assiut governorate and New Assiut city is very limited. Barriers to private sector development cause slow growth and capital flight.

Egypt - Ministry of State for Environmental Affairs

description.narrative: Bioenergy technology is widely used in at least four rural governorates.

comment.narrative: Bioenergy technology not widely accepted in rural areas.

description.narrative: To facilitate and accelerate the market development of new bioenergy technologies (BET) in Egypt, thereby promoting the sustainable socio-economic development of rural communities in Egypt and reducing the negative global and local environmental impacts associated with the use of fossil fuels and the environmentally unsound management of agricultural and solid waste. To remove the technical, institutional, information, financial, and market barriers to developing the bioenergy technology market in Egypt

comment.narrative: Lack of supportive policies to create a level playing field for BETs.
High level of confidence

457 household biogas units in 18 Governorates have now been installed either by the legally registered BSPs of trained engineers and masons or through the batches of training for 20 groups of an engineer and a mason. Total number of installed units till June 30, 2015 is 917 household biogas units.
More than 85% of the units are functioning well and producing biogas with great satisfaction communicated by the beneficiaries (households) through the monitoring sheets completed by the beneficiaries during the periodic monitoring visits of the BSPs and the project monitoring staff during random visits and phonecalls to benifichiaries..
20 groups, each consisting of one engineer and one mason, have participated in 50-day on-job training on building, curing, connecting and maintaining the household biogas units. The training took place in 5 governorates, namely; Fayoum, Assuit, Sharkeya, Beni Sweif and Menya. This btraining batch was not the project’s own trained engineers and masons but were trained by graduates of the first and second batches under the supervision of the project’s engineers and masons. Only 16 groups, each consisting of one engineer and one mason, finished their training as well as registering their documents and already entered the market after testing them theoretically and Practically.
The project succeeded in installing the biggest commercial biogas unit (50M3/day) in Fayoum in one of the big cattle farm. It is a German design and similar to the Indian design applied in the household units. It is installed by project masons under the supervision of project’s engineers. The installed commercial unit is now producing gas and bio fertilizer and project is in the process of generating electricity.
Lack of supportive policies to create a level playing field for BETs.
Average annual 20% market growth at the end of the project, as compared to the previous year.

Egypt is now moving towards adopting the feed-in-tariff for the biogas that is a very important step in the development of the country’s significant potential for renewable energy generation, while pursuing equally important economic, environmental and social policy objectives.
Egypt is continuing the gradually reducing fuel subsidies. This is already the case for diesel, gasoline and natural gas, and will soon also be applied to LPG cylinders. What added to the importance pf the biogas household units is that the paid cost of the units, especially with the cost share of the project, means that the payback time of the unit is just 24 months.
Lack of supportive policies to create a level playing field for BETs.
Supportive policy, including required financial and fiscal incentives, in place to sustain market growth.

The 295 family-size biogas units installed under the first and second waves of project installations have now been functioning well for more than thirty months and beneficiaries are satisfied. Additional biogas units are currently installed, either during the on-the-job training or by the legally registered BSPs.
As for the community units, the project has succeeded in installing Fifty Five larger units that each serves three households. The units have been functioning well for almost eighteen months.
One commercial size unit in a cattle farm is now working for more than three months and still working on electricity generation.
The project elaborated on the formal correspondence with governors of the potential governorates and organized orientation and introductory meeting for the Heads of Centers and Villages to talk to them about the project, its activities, importance of the biogas units and how to reach the companies. Dring the meetings, the project provided number of informative posters and brochures to put on governmental buildings to attract the biggest number of local citizens going there. This action increase number of beneficiaries and opened the market for the newly registered BSPs.
Five batches of 16 engineers and 16 masons were trained and now training is provided individually for each group in sight; in their home villages through project staff.

description.narrative: New business and financing models successfully introduced using appropriate technical solutions and demonstrating the possibility to construct and operate BET systems on a cost recovery basis under a supportive and enabling policy and financing environment.

comment.narrative: Lack of supportive policies to create a level playing field for BETs.
At least 1,000 family-scale, 10 community-scale and 2 farm-scale biogas systems constructed and commissioned by the end of the project.

e hired financial and management consultant worked with the registered BSPs, and provided draft financial data set with the purpose of assessing the financial feasibility and institutional set-up of a self-sustaining 'vehicle'. It is presented and approved by Project Steering Committee and started the process of registering this “Vehicle” as a Centralized Association under the name of “Bioenergy for Sustainable Rural Development Association”. The founder is a legal person representing Ministry of Environment, and the members of the Board of Trustees are also legal persons, representing the ministries and agencies that are members of project’s steering committee.
Lack of supportive policies to create a level playing field for BETs.
For gasification and/or combustion plants, at least 4 MW of installed new capacity reached by the end of the project.

To maintain beneficiaries’ satisfaction, BSPs have also been trained on the monitoring process. Their fees are contingent not only on successful construction of the units but also one year of monitoring of the units. BSPs are responsible to provide the project with a satisfactory certificate filled and signed by the beneficiary every three months to get the last four installments of unit’s price. Each installment is against a certificate and this covers a period of one year after gas production from any biogas unit.
Project’s monitoring staff are visiting random samples of functioning units and calling customers via phone periodically to assure their satisfaction and double check BSPs work. Monitoring is not only for the units installed by the but also for the units installed by the project as well as the trainees.
Lack of supportive policies to create a level playing field for BETs.
Over 90% of the customers satisfied with the new units

The project continued to urge governmental and non-governmental entities to support the idea and convince people to visit the installed units. The project also organized a number of seminars and meetings to introduce project activities and the liskt of kind donations provided by the project to encourage the spread of the technology.
The project signed a cooperation protocol with the Faculty of Agriculture, Menya University, on August 30, 2014, to provide technical assistance and spread biogas technology among faculty students. The Faculty will assist the project in analyzing bio-fertilizer and provide best ways of using it in cultivation. The project will assist the faculty to use its kitchen waste for biogas generation.
One of the biggest private Egyptian factories ‘Universal’ is manufacturing the biogas stoves that are not available in the local market and which was only available in the two governorates targeted by the project; namely, Fayoum and Assuit. After the wide spread of the project, it is required to be available everywhere and extra stoves should be sell in the market.

description.narrative: An enabling policy framework, effectively promoting rural bioenergy development, adopted.

comment.narrative: Lack of supportive policies to create a level playing field for BETs.

An enabling policy framework for promoting sustainable rural biomass energy adopted, including: recognition of BET and other renewable systems in official Government documents as the first option to be studied and considered for meeting rural energy needs, whenever technically and economically feasible

The cost-sharing of the project is an important factor in encouraging people to request more units, especially in the current context of rising fossil fuel prices. To continue the cost-sharing aspect of the project, a self-sustaining entity namely a Bioenergy for Sustainable Rural Development Association, is now developed and approved by Cabinet of Ministers to replace the project during its last quarter.
Lack of supportive policies to create a level playing field for BETs.

A level playing field for BET systems to compete with subsidized fossil fuels created and, as applicable, introduction of eventual additional financial or fiscal incentives to support BETs on the basis of their socio-economic and environmental benefits

A cooperation protocol was signed with Faculty of Agriculture, Menya University, on August 30, 2014, to provide technical assistance and spread biogas technology among faculty students. The Faculty will assist the project in analyzing bio-fertilizer and provide best ways of using it in cultivation. The project will assist the faculty to use its kitchen waste for biogas generation.
Cooperation is with the Small Grants Program to build the capacity of the granted NGOs by providing on-job training before helping their customers with biogas household units.
Lack of supportive policies to create a level playing field for BETs.
A supportive regulatory framework for managing the relations between the bioenergy service providers and the customers; Adoption of adequate product standards and quality control mechanisms.

The batches of training have been completed with 16 engineers and masons who are already tested and certified as biogas household service providers. The project worked on registering them legally BSPs through hired legal consultants. The role of the BSPs is to provide a comprehensive service, starting from awareness, application collections, site visits, installing the units, monitoring the gas production, and providing after-sales services for at least one full year (with periodic visits to the units) to assure beneficiary satisfaction. The project has to date registered tewenty BSPs and will continue to register others

description.narrative: Enhanced capacity of the local supply chain to market and deliver sustainable rural bioenergy products and services, including financing.

comment.narrative: Lack of supportive policies to create a level playing field for BETs.
At least 20 new local entities to serve as BSPs identified and their capacity built by the end of the first 18 months.

Currently, political support for the project is high, stemming notably from the Decree of the Board of Governors as well as welcoming the establishment of the Bioenergy for Sustainable Rural Development Association as a centralized association representing legal entities that are members of the PSC.
The project opened channels with universities in different Governorates that support awareness workshops and set elective courses during the coming academic years to boost the labour pool available to the bio-energy technology (BET) sector.
BSPs started their work in different Governorates, with the support of the project either through the awareness campaigns or application collection by EEAA RBOs. First 2 batched of BSBs will receive on-job training on the biggest commercial biogas unit during the last quarter of the year.
Lack of supportive policies to create a level playing field for BETs.
The follow-up activities and business of the trained BSPs show an increasing trend, leveraging financing from a variety of sources.

description.narrative: Institutionalization of the support provided by the project, including monitoring, learning, adaptive feedback and evaluation.

comment.narrative: Lack of supportive policies to create a level playing field for BETs.
An entity continuing the bioenergy market promotion after the project established and its funding secured

For the household biogas units, there is now accurate financial data for units of different sizes, using materials prices from local markets and empirical labour wage (man-day) rates. This data also includes the cost of the bioslurry that is generated from the installed unit compared to the chemical fertilizers that farmers use on their lands. The project is using this data to design a Self-Sustaining Biomass Energy Entity: the study will be published early next year.
The main aim of this study is to prepare policy guidelines for the project cycle in line with the pre-set strategy and guiding principles, complete the financial feasibility analysis and relevant cash flow analysis with regards to the "fund's" operations and possible scenarios regarding leveraging available balances in the short and medium term, and developing a draft institutional set up for the potential fund for discussion with project stakeholders.
Lack of supportive policies to create a level playing field for BETs.
Required information available during the implementation of the project for adaptive management, for measuring the impact and for effective replication/expansion of project activities.

The project’s detailed database on the received requests for biogas unit installations, the installed units and full information of the after-sales services provided is now available on the project’s local server and is accessible to project staff and BSPs. This has contributed to a sense of openness and inclusiveness with regard to the BSPs, which has fostered goodwill; it has also made project tracking and information retrieval much more straightforward

Concept Introduced&Replicated; NMT Model Share Increased/Sustained; Intro of TDM; Improved EE of Transport; Enhanced Awareness,Capacity; Monit., Learn.&Adptve Mngmnt

Complete establishment of a Variable Message Sign (VMS) system to direct car drivers to multi-story parking areas in Cairo City Center

11 Variable Message Sign system was in down town Cairo was launched connected to 13 multi-story parking areas in Cairo within the framework of a newly established integrated traffic lighting system
Construction of 14 Km Non Motorized Transport Corridor was established in Shebin El-Kom City

description.narrative:
To reduce the growth of energy consumption and related greenhouse gas emissions of the transport sector in Egypt, while simultaneously mitigating the local environmental and other problems of increasing traffic such as deteriorating urban air quality and congestion (Indicator: the growth rate of transport sector energy consumption).
To create an enabling policy and institutional environment and leverage resources for sustainable transport sector development, including the increasing or sustained modal share of public and non-motorized transportation, reduced use of private cars and more energy efficient freight transportation.
The status and impact of the pilot projects.

comment.narrative: The need for the proposed activities recognized, but the implementation suffering from different barriers.

The proposed pilot activities successfully concluded with the associated reduction of CO2 emissions by 1.48 million tonnes of CO2 equivalent (calculated for the pilot projects over 20 years from the project start) as a direct result of the project activities.

1) The Ministers of Transport, Housing, Utilities, and Urban Development, Environment, and the newly-appointed Giza Governor expressed full commitment to the protocol signed by their ministries and Governorate for implementing the pilot project.
The contract of the Delegation of Authority from Giza Governorate to the New Urban Communities Authority (NUCA) under the Ministry of Housing for bidding, operating and monitoring the five bus lines has been signed by both parties in July 2014.
NUCA’s Board of Directors, chaired by Minister of Housing and including six Ministers approved the project and incentive packages to private sector with some comments that were integrated into the tendering documents. The tender for implementing the pilot project connecting Greater Cairo with its satellite cities (6 October, Sheikh Zayed, and Media Production / Dreamland Cities) with integrated, high-quality public transportation has been issued in December2014 by the New Urban Communities Authority (NUCA) under the Ministry of Housing.
Estimated CO2 reductions from this pilot after 10 years will be about 120,000 tones of CO2.
2) The newly-appointed Menofia Governor confirmed commitment to the protocol signed by his Governorate with the Ministry of Environment for implementing the pilot project of the non-motorized transport corridor in Shebin El Kom City in Menofia Governorate. Two construction contracts covering the construction of the cycling tracks in Shebin El-Kom City were signed in 2014/2105
.A protocol was signed in September 2014 by the Ministry of Environment and Fayoum Governorate for implementing the pilot project of the non-motorized transport corridor in Fayoum City in Fayoum. Two construction contracts were signed covering construction of the cycling tracks were signed in 2015
3) Cairo Governorate is fully committed to the protocol signed with the Ministry of Environment for implementing the pilot project of the Variable Message Parking Signs (VMPS) in Cairo City Centre. The pilot has been implemented, the system has been installed, soft opening / commissioning has taken place in May 2015 by the Prime Minister, Ministry of Environment, Cairo Governor and UNDP within the framework of a launching an LE 50 million integrated traffic monitoring and control system in Cairo City Center. The Governor of Cairo issued a decree to prohibit car parking in Cairo City Center main streets which promoted the use and added value for the Variable Message Sign System .
Estimated CO2 reductions from this pilot after 10 years are about 2,000 tones of CO2.
4) Ministry of Environment and Ministry of Interior are coordinating to implement a pilot project for establishing integrated centers for vehicles environmental and technical inspection in Cairo Governorate.
The emissions factors for gasoline engines have been used for the calculation of GHG emissions from the Transport Sector in Egypt.
5) Activities of the AFD / French GEF Project, "Support To An Improved Urban Transport System In Cairo", continue to be implemented in synergy with the UNDP-implemented, GEF-financed project under the same Project Management Unit.
The activities of the AFD Project under implementation include:
a) Pilot project for improving Cairo Transit Authority El Nasr Garage to be a Green Garage by improving the environmental performance (management and maintenance practices); and
b) Completed a study on estimation and modeling of factors governing emissions of CO2 and other air pollutants from the public transport modes using diesel engines including buses, mini buses, & micro buses in Greater Cairo which complements the study done earlier by the UNDP-GEF project thus covering all means of transport in Greater Cairo.

description.narrative: Level of replication and/or expansion of the sustainable transport schemes promoted by the project

comment.narrative: The replication of the projects initiated as per the stated replication targets, including the leveraging of financial resources for the amount of at least USD 100 million for their future implementation.

Soft opening / commissioning of the Variable Message Parking Signs (VMPS) pilot in Cairo City Centre VMS has taken place, and Cairo Governorate intends to extend / replicate the system in other areas in Greater Cairo using the same project control room.
The pilot projects of the non-motorized transport corridor in Monofia and Fayoum are still under implementation, and they are expected to be completed during 3rd Quarter 2015. Ministry of Environment is coordinating with the New Urban Communities Authority (NUCA) under the Ministry of Housing for replicating the pilot after NUCA established a cycling lane in New Cairo adopting the same UNDP-GEF design and expressed plans to expand to the rest of the New Cities.
For replication, the project management is documenting the project pilot approaches, and the success stories after finalizing implementation any of the pilots, so as to present lessons-learned and recommended future options to the senior management of the relevant Government ministries. The project shall follow up closely to ensure that these options are inserted / integrated in the Ministries' future plans.

description.narrative: Level of adoption and implementation of the required policy and institutional changes

comment.narrative: The required policy and institutional development needs recognized and implemented by the Government.

description.narrative: The concept for new, integrated high-quality public transport services (to exert shift from private cars) for Cairo and its satellite cities successfully introduced and replicated on the basis of public-private partnerships.
The new public transport services continue to operate on a self-sustaining basis at the end of the project

comment.narrative: No adequate public transport services that can attract car users for the satellite cities available
The new public transport services introduced during the project continue to operate on a self-sustaining basis.

The project team completed all tendering documents for the pilot project to implement 3 new, high-quality public transportation bus services connecting Greater Cairo with 6th October City, Sheikh Zayed City, Media Production City / Dream Land to Metro line number 2 in Giza Governorate, as well as two feeder bus lines running in 6 October City and secured
The project team went through a long approval process for the tendering documents starting with technical staff then legal office in NUCA and ended up securing approval NUCA’s Board of Directors on the incentives package for the private sector given that it is the first contract of its type in Egypt.
The International tender was issued in December 2014 by the New Urban Communities Authority (NUCA) under the Ministry of Housing. The project team organized several meetings inviting interested private sector, businessmen associations, and commercial departments in Embassies to explain about the project
Several international and national companies / investors expressed interest and enthusiasm about the project and seven companies purchased the tender documents, but no proposals were received before the deadline which reflects private sector concerns given that the project is implemented in Egypt for the first time.
Project team in coordination with NUCA has conducted a series of meetings with the companies / investors to better understand their concerns about the tender. Accordingly, some modifications were introduced to the tender documents including an additional incentives for the investors, and retendering of the pilot project expected in July 2015.
2) The pilot project for executing a feeder bus public transportation system serving Saraya El Koba and Maadi Metro stations is still on hold by Cairo Governorate until the new Agency for Regulating Urban Transport in Greater Cairo, established under the Ministry of Transport, becomes operational. The Agency mandate in relation to Cairo Transit Authority (CTA) mandate still has to be specified and announced.

description.narrative: Proposals and agreements for replication are submitted and negotiated with the relevant authorities

comment.narrative: No feeder system that can attract car users for metro in place

Agreements for the replication of the concept of new, high quality and integrated (with citiesâ€™ internal public transport systems) inter-city bus services between Cairo and its 6 satellite cities formulated and discussed with the authorities

Proposals and agreements for replicating the establishment of new, high quality and integrated public bus transportation services connecting Cairo with its satellite cities will be formulated and discussed with the authorities in parallel with the pilot project implementation during Q4 2015. Nevertheless, NUCA is currently negotiating with EBRD to design new public transport bus lines and BRT system within 6 of October City to expand applications of the new contract after being tested in UNDP-GEF project.

description.narrative: The estimated amount of reduced GHG emissions by the pilot projects compared to the baseline

comment.narrative: Lack of experience with more advanced, road-based public transport systems such as BRT.
Successful demonstration and agreement of the Government for replication of an integrated feeder bus and ticketing system for 9 existing and for 5 new metro stations in Cairo.

Demonstration and agreement with the Government for replication of the integrated feeder bus and ticketing system for Metro stations in Greater Cairo will start in parallel with the pilot project implementation during Q4 2015.
Ministry of Transport, Ministry of Housing, and Giza Governorate are very supportive of the concept / objectives of the pilot project for connecting the new cities with Greater Cairo via high-quality public transportation bus services integrated with the Metro lines, and they are planning to replicate this approach on a larger scale in their future plans.

description.narrative: The modal share of non-motorized transport in middle-size provincial cities increased or sustained.
Modal share of NMT in the targeted cities

comment.narrative: 52% in Shebin El-Kom (down from 68% in 1988) and 31% in Fayoum
The estimated current NMT modal share in the targeted cities sustained or increased

1) Menofia Governorate has contributed with more than LE 20 million for developing and upgrading the infrastructure and the utilities in the network of roads of the NTM pilot project against LE 4 million from STP which exceeded the 50% requested contribution of Menofia Governorate. The pilot project in Menofia is under implementation, and most of the construction activities in the 6 corridors have been completed .
2) Co-funding of the pilot project in Fayoum was provided by the Egyptian Social Fund for Development (SFD) with L.E 2.6 million as part of the local contribution according to the protocol signed between Fayoum Governorate and SFD, and that part has been implemented and construction activities have been completed. Remaining activities of the pilot in Fayoum, with an estimated total cost of about L.E 5.4 million, has been tendered for construction in November 2014, the winning company has been contracted, and construction is progressing well.
3) The project continued coordinating with the GEF Small Grants Programme (SGP) in Egypt in the context of organizing and following-up on the participation of the local NGOs (three NGOs from Menofia and two from Fayoum) signed Memorandums of Agreement with SGP in implementing some of the pilot project activities in Menofia and Fayoum Governorates. The total of GEF SGP grants for the 5 NGOs is approximately $200,000. The NGOs in Menofia and Fayoum with full support of the STP have been implementing intensive awareness campaigns in the 1st and 2nd Quarter 2015 according to the detailed plan for implementing these campaigns agreed on by SGP, STP, EEAA,UNDP and the local authorities in the 2 Governorates. The SGP has also established a revolving funds to support youth buying bicycles and initiated installation of cycling parking racks all over the two cities.
Results achieved to date are a good indicator for the PMU that the pilot NMT corridors are regarded as an urban development initiative that supports behavioral change; accordingly, it is envisaged that the corridors will enable the project, by 2015, to achieve its target for sustaining / increasing the modal share of NMT.

description.narrative: Number of kilometres of new NMT corridors constructed and used

comment.narrative: A total of 50km of new NMT corridors constructed and used by the end of the project

The NMT corridors that have been constructed in Menofia Governorate covers a length of 14 km. Similarly, in Fayoum Governorate, the NMT corridors under construction will also cover a length of 14 Kms . The total length of the NMT corridors in Menofia and Fayoum is therefore about 28 km.

description.narrative: The estimated amount of reduced GHG emissions by the selected pilot projects compared to the baseline.

comment.narrative: Reduced CO2 emissions of 0.26 million tons of CO2 equivalent (calculated for the pilot projects over 20 years from the project start) as a direct result of the project activities

The CO2 emissions to be reduced as a direct result of the project activities will be estimated in Q4 2015. The CO2 emission reductions have not yet been achieved and the future expected reductions will be known within 6 months of the operation of the NMT corridors.

description.narrative: Successful introduction of the Transport Demand Management (TDM) concept with an objective to expand it towards more aggressive measures over time to effectively discourage the use of private cars, when good quality public transport services are available.
The level of enforcement of the piloted TDM measures

comment.narrative: No real strategy currently in place to effectively proceed with TDM in order to reduce local air pollution and congestion in Greater Cairo area and Alexandria and simultaneously contribute to GHG reduction
The pilot TDM measures effectively enforced and respected by car users

1) Concerning the TDM pilot project for applying a bus priority system at traffic signals in Moustafa El Nahas Corridor is still on hold as Cairo Governorate did not approve tendering the design, supply, installation and maintenance of the transit priority system. Cairo Governorate has been working on developing the whole Moustafa El Nahas Corridor, and constructed a segregated bus lane.
2) The TDM pilot project for introducing Variable Message Parking Signs (VMS) to guide cars to the appropriate parking facilities around the City Centre in Cairo Governorate has been implemented by a consortium of Italian / Egyptian companies in coordination with Cairo Governorate authorities. A high-level committee chaired by Cairo Governorate Secretary General, and with the participation of high government officials from Cairo Governorate, UNDP, EEAA, project management and experts has been meeting intensively to follow up on the progress of implementing the pilot, and to solve problems that might cause delay.
The VMS system includes 14 signs in the surroundings of the City Centre connected with 10 parking areas.
The consortium of the Italian / Egyptian companies that was contracted to implement the pilot has conducted the following activities:
- Field surveys and investigations to identify the existing utilities in the VMS locations;
- Manufacturing the components of the VMS system in Italy, and transporting it to Egypt;
- Civil, mechanical and electrical works for installing and operating the VMS system; and
- Install the equipment in the Operation Control Center (OCC).
A committee from representatives of the Ministry of Environment / EEAA, Cairo Governorate, project management and experts has attended and approved the Factory Acceptance Test (FAT) conducted in Italy in December 2014 on the different components of the VMS system, and the Site Acceptance Test (SAT) conducted in Cairo in May 2015 on the VMS system after being installed.
Cairo Governorate has provided and furnished a center to be used for the operation control of the VMS system.
The pilot project has been implemented, and the system installed in full coordination with Cairo Governorate
Soft opening / commissioning has taken place in May 2015 by the Prime Minister, Ministry of Environment, Cairo Governor and UNDP. Fine tuning and testing of the system is going on.

description.narrative: The level of satisfaction of the key stakeholders on the effectiveness of the TDM measures introduced

comment.narrative: High satisfaction of the key stakeholders on the effectiveness of the TDM measures introduced and on the quality of the alternative public transport services provided

1) The TDM pilot project for applying bus priority system at traffic signals in Moustafa El Nahas Corridor has been put on hold by Cairo Governorate as it has been studying the integration of that system with the development of the whole Moustafa El Nahas Corridor, that included a segregated bus lane that Cairo Governorate has constructed in the corridor.
2) The TDM pilot project for introducing variable message parking signs (VMS) to guide cars to the appropriate parking facilities around the city centre in Cairo Governorate has been implemented, and commissioning of the system took place. In fast survey, car owners over Facebook expressed satisfaction with the new system.

description.narrative: The estimated amount of reduced GHG emissions by the selected pilot projects compared to the baseline

comment.narrative: Agreement of the local governments to replicate and/or expand the pilot TDM measures in the Greater Cairo Area and, if applicable, Alexandria

After the successful implementation of the variable message parking signs (VMS) pilot project, Cairo Governorate is studying the possibility to extend the VMS system to other parts in Cairo. The VMS system was designed to accommodate more signs inside and outside Cairo that can be managed through the same control room.

description.narrative: Improved energy efficiency of freight transport
Fuel consumption and the associated GHG emissions per ton and km of goods transported

comment.narrative: Inefficient operation of the existing truck fleet
Reduced CO2 emissions of 0.85 million tons of CO2 equivalent (calculated for the pilot projects over 20 years from the project start) as a direct result of the project activities

The Ministries of Environment and Interior (MoI) have been working together to implement a pilot project for issuing licenses to the private sector specialized companies to establish integrated centers in Cairo Governorate for vehicles technical and environmental inspection for issuing / renewing licenses of these vehicles.
Also, there was coordination between the MoI and the United Arab Emirates Government for providing technical and financial support for the design and construction of these centers.

description.narrative: Fuel consumption and the associated GHG emissions per ton and km of goods transported

comment.narrative: Low utilization of the available rail and river based freight transport options
Over 100,000 tons savings in fuel consumption as a result of the project activities by the end of the project.

Discussions have been ongoing between the Ministries of Environment and Transport on the appropriate sustainable transport measures to be adopted by the Ministry of Transport and can be supported by the project, according to the report prepared by the project with recommendations to improve national freight transport on road, rail and river.

description.narrative: Strengthened institutional capacity to promote sustainable transport sector development during and after the project.
The progress with the institutional reforms and other improvements needed

comment.narrative: The level of awareness and capacity of the key stakeholders as well as the level of adoption and implementation of the required legal, regulatory and institutional changes to facilitate sustainable transport sector development still low

For all outcomes: Adoption of a national, sustainable transport policy addressing the key requirements and setting concrete short, medium and long term targets in different key areas the project is addressing

The project has analyzed the results of the field measurements conducted and the huge data-set collected in the field study for determination of the fuel-based emission factors of private cars and taxis with gasoline engines in Greater Cairo, and has continued the study to determine the emission factors based on travel distance of the cars (g/km) - i.e. activity-based emission factors. The generated emission factors were integrated in the Third National Communication Report to UNFCCC for Egypt. The project has used the on-board measurements to construct a local drive cycle representing the traffic pattern in Greater Cairo, which has been used to estimate activity-based emission factors.
A training was organized for the relevant staff in the Environmental Agency on the data acquisition and analysis for estimating the emission factor The “Support To An Improved Urban Transport System in Cairo” Project funded by AFD / French GEF (also managed by the UNDP-GEF Project Management Unit) has continued conducting a complementary field study for determination of fuel-based emission factors of diesel engine vehicles (buses, minibuses and micro buses) under local driving conditions in Greater Cairo using on-board measuring equipment.

For Outcome 1: Enhanced capacity of the Ministry of Transport and its underlying agencies in the area of sustainable transport to effectively co-ordinate the development of the public transport systems in Cairo and other major urban centers in Egypt.

1) The Project / EEAA has been coordinating with the new Agency for Regulating Urban Transport in Greater Cairo, under the Ministry of Transport, to investigate the opportunities to assist in building its capacity, and developing its organization.
2) The Project / EEAA has also being coordinating with the Ministry of Transport and its underlying agencies (river, rail authorities and the General Authority for Roads, Bridges and Land Transport, GARBLT) to investigate the opportunities to assist in building their capacity in the area of sustainable transport to effectively co-ordinate the development of the public transport systems in Cairo and other major urban centers in Egypt.

For Outcome 2: The non-motorized transport (NMT) modal share in Fayoum and Shebin El Kom cities sustained or increased, and the capacity of the local authorities in the 2 Governorates enhanced to develop and implement NMT. Social acceptance of cycling, and NMT supply side services in the 2 cities increased.

The project has developed a Communication and Environmental Awareness program that are being executed in cooperation with the GEF Small Grants Programme (SGP) in Egypt via SGP-funded NGOs.
The partner NGOs in Shebin El-Kom and Fayoum held two public largecycling events, marking the beginning of the pilot projects and the awareness campaign. The events helped to introduce the STP and its pilots to the broad community and the media.
The project launched awareness campaign on cycling and walking in parallel in the two cities with the initiation of the construction works. Several cycling events were organized in the two cities with participation of senior officials from the Ministry of Environment, Ministry of Youth and Sport and the respective Governorate. Cycling events attracted hundreds of youth in the two cities. Bicycles were offered as awards to a number of youth who participated in the events and Ministry of Social Solidarity offered down payments for new bicycles for 100 people. Cyclists groups from Cairo and Alexandria were invited to participate and share experience with the newly established cyclist groups in the two cities.
Several awareness-raising seminars have been conducted by the NGOs in cooperation with the project team over the period from January-June 2015. Four seminars in Fayoum, and three in Menofia were held targeting school and university students, youths, women, workers as well as bus and taxi drivers. Over 450 persons attended the different seminars in Fayoum, and more than 850 persons in Shebin El-Kom. The project is currently preparing awareness videos that will be used by the NGOs in the seminars.
A public awareness campaign under the name "Let's Cycle for a Better Community" was launched in January through June 2015 . The campaign aims to raise the social acceptance of cycling and to lower the barriers to bicycle purchase and use in the two governorates, where the STP Pilots are being implemented.
The project encouraged the partner NGOs to establish amateur cycling groups in their governorates. The newly established groups in the two cities started activities with creating their Facebook pages and organizing several rides occasionally.To further support the new cycling groups,STP provided the groups with the opportunity to do joint activities with professional cycling groups and participate in their events in Cairo and Alexandria.
The project also continued coordinating with the Swedish Institute in Alexandria and the Green Arm of Nahdat El-Mahrousa NGO to support the cycling and walking campaigns that the project is conducting.
The successful implementation of the pilot project activities will help in increasing the social acceptance of cycling and will enhance the supply of supporting services such as trade, maintenance and repair of bicycles, and encourage the local authorities in the two Governorates to replicate them in other provincial cities. It will also lead to an increase of the NMT modal share in the two Governorates.
The local authorities in the two Governorates are fully supporting the implementation of the pilots, and provided their contributions to the construction cost.

For Outcome 3: Subject to the agreement with the local authorities, a semi-public parking authority to implement and, in close collaboration with other key authorities, to enforce parking policies (conducive to sustainable transport sector development principles), if possible, established by the end of the project and its capacity built.

The frequent change in senior government officials since 2011,has made it difficult to set up new institutional and regulatory frameworks for parking policies in Cairo’s Central Business District (CBD). That was discussed with the Evaluator in the Mid-Term Review conducted in 2012 and it was agreed to cancel this output.
For Outcome 4: Enhanced capacity of the Ministry of Transport and its underlying agencies to develop and implement sustainable transport policies and actions in the field of freight transport

1) Project experts continued to provide technical support and enhance the capacity of the Egyptian Environmental Affairs Agency (EEAA) technical staff concerning sustainable transport, vehicle emissions factors, vehicles emissions and control.
2) The project has been preparing a training programme for the local authority officials and engineers in the main cities for building their capacity in integrated urban land use and transport planning for sustainable passenger transport and sustainable freight transport. The training programme shall be conducted in Q4 2015.

description.narrative: Monitoring, learning, adaptive feedback and evaluation
The required information available for adaptive management, for measuring the impact and for effective replication/expansion of the project activities

comment.narrative: Inadequate information for adaptive management, for measuring the impact and for effective replication/expansion of the project activities
The required information available for adaptive management, for measuring the impact of the project and for effective replication/expansion of the project activities

In spite of the many changes in the positions of senior government officials in recent years, the project succeeded to get all required political support, to renew the approvals of the new senior officials in Ministries and Governorates for the pilot projects, and to get their commitment for providing the local contribution in the implementation cost of the pilots.
All pilot projects have been under implementation, except the pilot connecting Greater Cairo with its satellite cities with integrated, high-quality public transportation shall be retendered in July 2015.
Construction of the NMT pilot in Menofia Governorate has nearly been completed, and VMS pilot in Cairo Governorate has been implemented and commissioned.
In light of the political stability over the last year, the project has pursued an adaptive strategy through 2014 / 2015, in which the project management continued to exert efforts to sign protocols with the relevant authorities for implementing the remaining pilot projects, in which commitment and responsibilities of all parties / stakeholders were identified and agreed on. Also, to expedite implementation of all pilot projects, and to have big percentage of the construction works completed during 1st half of 2015.

description.narrative: Participatory Regional, National & Governorate Strategic Planning for Balanced Spatial Development (SPAD)
The Participatory National, Regional and Governorate Strategic Planning for Balanced Spatial Development (SPAD) Project

- National Strategic Plan methodology for developing land use plans for growth corridors prepared. - Regional strategic guidelines (printouts, CDs and website) in place. - Strategic Plan for Suez Canal Economic Region prepared and available for implementation. - Strategic Plan for North Upper Egypt Economic Region prepared and available for implementation. - A regional/governorate strategic guidelines document in place - Five Strategic Governorate Plans in Suez Canal Region prepared and available for implementation. - Two Strategic Governorate Plans in North Upper Egypt Region prepared and available for implementation - Action plans for Zifta and Awlad Sakr prepared. - The information management policies are implemented. - A full network and data exchange system is running between RPPC number 3 and local authorities

comment.narrative: - There is an Egyptian National 2017 Spatial Plan but it does not include a long term vision or strategies to address issues related to urban growth and expansions in a holistic approach. - The problem of uncontrolled population growth and encroachment of conurbations on agricultural land is increasing. It currently presents a serious challenge to development and social prosperity. - Opportunities for urban development and growth exist but have not been incorporated into planning. - Lack of strategic plans on the regional level. - Applied planning methods are not documented and depend mainly on individual experiences. - A gap exists between planning at the national level (socio-economic national plans) and the local levels (city and village planning). The result is usually an inefficient interrelationship between planning objectives and strategies at both levels. - Lack of strategic plans on the governorate level. - Applied planning methods are not documented and depend mainly on individual experiences. - A gap exists between planning at the national level (socio-economic national plans) and the local levels (city and village planning). The result is an inefficient connection between planning objectives and strategies at both levels. - All seven regional centers are currently connected and networked with GOPP headquarters but the connection is not yet utilized. - Several policies and guidelines related to data standardization and information management are currently available. However they have not been fully implemented. - RPPCs and local authority's staff are characterized by low capacity in working within computer-based networked environment, and lack experience in using corporate GIS techniques. - Follow-up of plans is only on the financial aspects or economic plans – spatial plans have almost no examples of follow-up, let alone evaluation.

description.narrative: Objective: Establishment of a sustainable protected area financing system, with associated management structures, systems and capacities needed to ensure the effective use of generated revenues for priority biodiversity conservation needs

At project end, achieved levels of revenue are within 10% of projection and the trend in growth rates sets the NCS on track to meet the optimal scenario by year 10[1]
At least two new, reliable sources of funds are established

According to the official reports on financing of PA system during reporting year, a general indicator shows remarkable progress where $2.5m was allocated as a governmental budget and $1.7m was allocated to PAs as co-sharing for the project toward optimal scenario of PA management.
In cooperation with “Support protected Areas” project, under Italian cooperation, $ 0.5m was allocated for upgrading the PAs infrastructure, equipments and staff capacities.
Financial reports of NCS show that PA revenues generated during 2015 is approx. $9 million including PAs entrance fees and concessions and
Two new management systems were prepared (Northern Red Sea Islands and Wadi Degla Protected Areas); the eight priority PAs now all use a consistent format.
The management system plans for the eight priority PAs were revised (including the overall management strategy, work plans and budgets) to align with NCS’s new Strategic Plan (2014).
Four management system plans have been submitted to NCS for revision, and four are remaining. They will all be revised until approved by EEAA. Once approved, the project can ensure allocation of the set budget from both EEAA and the project budget.
A Concession Committee has been founded to prepare the RFPs for any concession projects (touristic activities/vistor center) within three PAs (Wadi Rayan, Wadi Degla and Wadi El Gemal) and this will generate revenues of $2.2 million over 10 years and will be re-evaluated after 10 years, which will be proposed for bidding.

Two new management systems were developed in 2015 (Wadi Degla and Red Sea Northern Islands) with approximately all PAs staff present. The remaining six management plans were reviewed with PA managers to match the new NCS strategic plan. All the management systems were changed to a standard format and the financial plans were reviewed by an NCS financial planner. The project also participated in the Economic Forum in March of 2015 where the possible investments within PAs were presented, as well as organizing a workshop for tour guides and tour operators in Egypt.

Enhanced resilience of Nile Delta Coastal area, on approximately 2,504 km2, due to adaptation measures.

comment.narrative: North coast of Egypt is characterized by high vulnerability to impacts of sea level rise.

description.narrative: Objective: to integrate the management of SLR risks into the development of Egyptâ€™s Low Elevation Coastal Zone (LECZ) in the Nile Delta
Enhanced resilience of Nile Delta coastal area on approximately 2,504 km2 due to adaptation measures (e.g. beach nourishment, vegetative buffers, sand placement and dune stabilization)

comment.narrative: North coasts of Egypt are characterized by high vulnerability to impacts of SLR. SLR will inundate land and coastal infrastructure and will also result in seawater intrusion will also further change the offshore water current patterns resulting in beach erosion and change in the shoreline which has its negative impact on tourism. SLR will also deteriorate coastal Mediterranean wetlands and induce stress on fisheries in the coastal lagoons. Furthermore, SLR. The government has been investing in â€œhardâ€? coastal protective measures that often diminish the robustness of the coast to anticipated SLR.

At least three types of resilience-enhancing measures employed by the project upon its completion in each of the three main coastal lagoons, (Idku, Burullus and Manzala coastal lagoons), covering 60% of coastal area of concern.

Project Management Unit (PMU) focused on implementing the soft measures in Damiatta and Rosetta to Burullus.
In Damiatta, several meetings have been held between the Damiatta Port Authority (DPA), Shore Protection Authority (SPA) and Coastal Research Institute (CoRI). A road map was signed on 21 January 2015 detailing the steps that will be undertaken by each organisation to nourish the eroding breaches near Damiatta with the dredged material from the approach channel of the port.
For the second pilot site (Rosetta to Burullus) where a dike application is tested as a means to protect the area and the international Coastal Road, The selected site for the pilot is nearly flooded each year at high storms. SPA contracted a contractor (ARC Marine) to construct the dike. A site visit was made with the contractor's representative. Construction will start in July 2015.
The PMU also held eight meetings with the project management and executive committees to discuss the progress of the project activities, present any obstacles and recommend ways forward. These meetings proved to be very useful as many obstacles were overcome and many good recommendations were made.
The PMU has also met HE the Minister of Water Resources and Irrigation three times. The first meeting was as part of MWRI Climate Change Committee meeting and was to present the progress made during the year and get HE feedback on this progress. The second and third meeting were to discuss how to move forward the ICZM study after the cancellation of the EU tender. Based upon these meeting, the PMU with the UNDP prepared a letter to the EU which was signed by the HE the Minister explaining the importance of having an ICZM plan for the north coast of Egypt and asking the EU to re reinstate the previously allocated funds for the ICZM and re-tender the study.

description.narrative: Percentage of Shoreline protection agency budget includes coastal stabilization measures designed by the project.

comment.narrative: Target is likely to be achieved in. SPA is now convinced that soft measures would help in protecting the long reaches of the shoreline (10s of Kilometers) that is subjected to erosion. SPA has provided good suggestions for the two pilot sites and keen to implement them and maintain them even beyond the project end. It is anticipated that once the pilot projects are implemented, SPA will keep on monitoring them and provide budget to maintain them at high condition grade

Target is still likely to be achieved in. SPA is co-financing the dike pilot application in Rosetta to Burullus. SPA will also monitor the performance of the three implemented alternatives. The best alternative(s) will be implemented by SPA from its own budget.

description.narrative: Outcome 1: strengthened Regulatory Framework and Institutional Capacity to improve resilience of coastal settlements and development infrastructure
A comprehensive regulatory and institutional framework for coastal adaptation built around ICZM principles and policies in place

comment.narrative: Existing drafts of ICZM policies but donâ€™t account for sea level rise, and were never implemented; only certain specialized staff has knowledge of concrete adaptation measures. Information management systems reflect risks, but not climate-induced risks to CZ. Existing budgetary allocations are insufficient to meet identified adaptation needs
By end of the project national ICZM plan finalized, agency assigned to implement and carry out M&E

The Project team has continued to provide technical support to MWRI, SPA, the Egyptian-Dutch Advisory Panel Project on Water (APP) and the EU to finalize the ICZM plan ToR and procurement. The tender was announced by the EU in July 2014. The project manager helped in evaluating the received EoIs and the shortlisting process. From October 2014 to December 2015, the project manager evaluated with the EU representatives the received offers from 6 contractors. Regrettably, the requests of the first two shortlisted companies to change key members of the project team with less competent professionals, have made their offers non complaint as per the EU procurement rules and accordingly, the tender was cancelled in December 2014.
Since the ICZM Plan is expected to be the guiding framework for all development and shore protection activities in the North Coast of Egypt at least for the next decade, the PMU suggested that part of the funds from the UNDP-GEF Climate Change Adaptation Project (approx. USD 250k) is used to initiate the scooping phase of the Plan over the next couple of months. This proposal was presented to HE the Minister of Water Resources and Irrigation and the Project Executive Committee members who approved this proposal. In mean time, the PMU and UNDP will continue to help the Ministry to secure the remaining funds to enable developing the ICZM Plan in the shortest possible time frame.

description.narrative: Enhanced data management systems to improve ICZM decision-making in place

comment.narrative: By end of the project NCZMC re-activated and given necessary authority to implement and monitor ICZM and coastal zone decisions. Its members are engaged, committed with clear responsibilities and capacity to carry out responsibilities

The recruitment process to select a consultant to "Design a National Coastal Observation System for the North Coast of Egypt" was initiated in the last quarter of 2014. The consultancy ToR was advertised on the UNDP – International website from 14 to 28 October 2014. The project received eight applications but none of them were believed to have the relevant experience. The project accordingly sought assistance from the ClimaSouth project and the UNDP Bangkok Regional office to obtain additional CVs and four additional CVs were received.
The most relevant of those four CVs was from Prof. Nadia Pinardi who then apologized due to her busy schedule. Therefore, only three CVs were evaluated by a committee from SPA,CoRI, PMU and UNDP. The process took longer time than expected in order to ensure that selected consultant can undertake this crucial and important task. At the end the committee selected Dr David Glenn Aubrey to carry out this consultancy. This selection was presented to and approved by the Project Executive Committee. Dr Aubrey was contracted in May 2015 and undertaken a two week visit to Egypt in 9-22 May 2015 to assess the existing monitoring capabilities in Egypt. it is anticipated that David will complete the design by November 2015. Meanwhile, the project will support procurement of the first monitoring equipment to be installed in the system.

description.narrative: SPA budget lines earmarked specifically for adaptive capacity

comment.narrative: SPA has mandate, skills and tools to screen current and future investments for climate risk;

Still not initiated. The change in SPA mandate is linked to the work on the new law and the development of a new institutional setup for ICZM as well as the work on the development of ICZM Plan. Meanwhile the introduction of new budget lines will be associated with the completion of the ICZM Plan
At least 30 personnel from relevant institutions are trained in climate risk assessment and economic valuation methods;
The target has been achieved but the capacity building activities will continue with the on the job training on the design and implementation of the soft engineering solutions.

This is now part of the National observation system consultancy. Part of its outputs is to develop an information management system and establish data protocols and data quality control guidelines. this is likely to be ready by the end of 2015.

description.narrative: Outcome 2. Strategies and measures that facilitate adaptation to climate change impacts, SLR in particular, are implemented on the ground in vulnerable coastal areas

Living Shoreline approach adopted to sustain functions and productivity in each of the vulnerable lagoons, in the face of sea level rise, through preserving existing wetlands and lagoon ecosystems and enhancing their functionality.

comment.narrative: To date, shore protection has been dominated by hard protection measures; lagoon functionality and productivity is at risk due to predominantly non-climate factors.
Nourishment, plant/stone/sand fill placement allow for coast stabilization and ensure that lagoon borders are at least 2.0 m above lagoons water level

For the first pilot site In Damiatta (nourishment of eroding beaches), several meetings have been held between the Damiatta Port Authority (DPA), Shore Protection Authority (SPA) and Coastal Research Institute (CoRI). A road map was signed on 21 January 2015 detailing the steps that will be undertaken by each organisation to nourish the eroding breaches near Damiatta with the dredged material from the approach channel of the port. In this road map, the following was agreed:
1- SPA to build sedimentation basins beside the western wall of the port from the project budget.
2- DPA to dump the dredged materiel into the sedimentation basins which is estimated to cost LE 60 million to be paid by DPA
3- SPA to transfer the dredged material from the sedimentation basins to nourish the eroding beaches in Damiatta area to be paid from SPA’s own budget.
4- PMU to explore available options to extract the black sand from the dredged material with relevant organisations in Egypt such as the Nuclear Material Authority (NMA). A monthly meeting is held with all parties to follow up the progress of the implementation of the road map. to date the following progress has been made:
1- SPA selected a contractor to build the sedimentation basins and a contract will be signed in July 2015.
2- DPA selected a contractor to dredge the approach channel and he/she will dump the material in the sedimentation basin.
3- SPA will nourish the eroding breached once 1 and 2 above are on going
4- PMU met with the chairman of NMA and the senior project manager of the black sand project in Egypt. It was agreed that more samples will be taken and analysed from the dredged material to ensure economic feasibility of the extraction of the black sand. A meeting was also held with a DPA representative to coordinate this process.
In addition to the above the PMU has recruited a consultant to assess the economic Feasibility of using the dredged
material from Damietta Port approach channel for sand nourishment. This study was undertaken based on a recommendation from the project steering and executive committees.
Wastewater discharge
Re-vegetation to stabilize seabed sediment (Idku lagoon)
has changed pH and reduced lagoon productivity;
depletion of fisheries As a result of the human activities and land
Beach nourishment, plant/stone/sand fill placement allow for coast stabilization and maintenance of lagoon border at least 2.5m above water level (Burullus lagoon).

Further to the previous studies undertaken by CoRI, the PMU contracted a team of researchers to carry out and economic feasibility assessment of using dredged material from Damietta port approach channel for sand nourishment. The main objectives of the study were to:
(1) Assess the present and future costs (up to 2050) of the following:
current dredging techniques into the offshore areas, extraction of black sand from dredged material, protection of nearby areas using the dredged material as a source for sand nourishment, hard solutions and other sources.
(2) Evaluate of the economic feasibility of a number of possible shoreline protection alternatives as possible mean for combating erosion at the nearby areas and select the best viable protection measure based on end results of
this evaluation.
(3) Assess how beneficial the nourishment approach could facilitate better sustainable future adaptation to climate change for other recipient areas in the Nile Delta.
The study concluded that the option of beach nourishment is found to be most appropriate for protection areas near Damietta port, whereas a combination of groins and sand nourishment seems to be more relevant for the area east of Ezzbet Elborg.
reclamation projects, total
area of El Burullus lagoon reduced during last century from 5,600 km3 (1925) to 317.2
Beach nourishment, plant/stone/sand fill placement allow for coast stabilization and maintenance of lagoon border at least 2.5m above water level in both the lagoon and canal;

For the second pilot site (Rosetta to Burullus) where a dike application is tested as a means to protect the area and the international Coastal Road, the following progress has been made:
- A topographic survey was completed for the area to find suitable locations for the pilot application.
- SPA and CoRI staff selected three suitable locations based upon the survey
- A site visit was undertaken by SPA, CoRI and PMU to check the conditions at each of the selected locations.
- A final selection was made based on the site visit. The selected site is nearly flooded each year at high storms.
- SPA and CoRI staff designed 3 dike alternatives which will be constructed at the selected location to find out the best option (s).
- SPA tendered the job and undertaken technical and financial evaluation of the received offers.
- SPA contracted a contractor (ARC Marine) to construct the dike.
- A site visit was made with the contractor's representative.
- Construction will start in July 2015.
km3 (1984) and now 197.8 km3 (2001); urban sewage and agriculture drainage has led to eutrophication.

The Manzala lagoon is the largest and most productive Lake in terms of its fisheries, estimated annual fish landings is roughly 60,000 tons. Since 1965, it has been receiving increasing amounts of agricultural runoff, industrial waste discharge, and sewage effluent that have led to eutrophication, decreased biodiversity, and reduced habitat for marine and avian species.
Erosion rate held constant and begins to decline to by .5 m/yr (Manzala lagoon);
By end of the project methods and practice of climate riks assessment, socio-economic valuation (CBA) of adaptation options are established as part of the ICZM framework

A Social Insurance system is integrated with functioning call centers, a website for the social insurance authority. An effective project management is established. Reports and studies are conducted about Policy and technical support provided for the Minister of finance. The PPP approach to government investment projects is monitored.

comment.narrative: MOF is an economic actor in Egypt’s development, but it has played so far a traditional role as a controller of income and expenditures only. The project aims at supportinging MoF as an economic actor in Egypt’s development. MOF’s traditional role of being the government’s financial arm and controller of income and expenditure was extended to being the source of macro-fiscal policy advice to the government during the last cooperation phase with UNDP furthermore, by focusing on the restructuring and automation of the Authority for Social Insurance. The MOF is further increasing its social and economic impact, in line with the role of financial ministries in developed countries.

• Implement reform activities in Internal Audit and automate Full payroll • Provide technical assistance to Macro-fiscal policy unit • Support international & regional events and legal advice • Build the Capacity of Public Private Partnership (PPP) unit

• The first “Strategic Planning Forum” was organized during 2015 to develop MOF’s vision, strategic goals in cooperation. A second forum targeting the development of tactical targets and the high level strategic plan for the ministry is planned for early 2016. • Internal Audit roadmap and IT unit’s mandate are being developed. • Payroll automation Studies have been conducted and are being reviewed. • Monthly memos covering main macroeconomic and fiscal updates, pension law, and global economic development were prepared. • Several meetings and events with representatives from various investment banks, international development agencies, banks, embassies and International Financial Institutions were organized. • Trainings and workshops for 30 PPP unit employees were conducted. • PPP projects were promoted in several regional and international conferences and summits. • The tendering process of the new 8 PPP projects that were announced in the Egypt Economic Development Conference (EEDC) held in Sharm el sheikh has beeb started by PPP unit.

title.narrative: Strategic Urban Planning for Alexandria City till 2032

description.narrative: Strategic Urban Planning for Alexandria City till 2032
The project seeks to develop a Strategic Urban Plan for Alexandria City to guide development in the city till year 2032, reflecting the Governorate's vision and goals
seat of a first-order administrative division

- A strategic plan for Alexandria city is prepared - A new city boundary is delimited and implemented - A socio-economic plan is activated - Local staff capable of implementing and following-up on plans and actions. - A full network and data exchange system is running between Alexandria regional center and the local planning authority. - An urban management strategy prepared and implemented in Alexandria - An urban information system is running. - Annual city state reports produced. - A Capital Investment plan is produced and adopted by the local authority. - TORs for detailed and action plans produced and used by the local authority

comment.narrative: - The current land use plan and administrative boundaries of Alexandria city is outdated and don’t meet the need for future growth. - The problem of uncontrolled population growth and encroachment of conurbations around the city is increasing. It currently presents a serious challenge to development and social prosperity. - Opportunities for urban development and growth exist but have not been incorporated into strategic planning. - Alexandria regional center is currently connected and networked with GOPP headquarters but the connection is not yet utilized. - Alexandria regional center and local authority’s staff are characterized by low capacity in working within computer-based networked environment, and lack of experience using corporate GIS techniques. - Low capacity at the local level in implementing Strategic Urban Planning (SUP), monitoring or evaluating actions and plans. - Follow-up on plans takes place only on the financial and economic aspects. - Lack of an urban management strategy and implementation mechanisms. - Inefficient land administration system - Lack of a clear M&E system for development follow-up - Low involvement of local communities in monitoring and evaluating the implementation of plans which reduces the sense of ownership among citizens.

comment.narrative: Implement 15 energy efficient lighting pilot projects Establish at least one energy efficiency testing laboratory

The project completed 20 energy efficient lighting pilot projects in hotels, banks, government buildings, residential compounds, administration buildings, libraries, etc.
The testing laboratory for the fans has been completed

description.narrative: To improve the energy efficiency of end-use equipment, namely building appliances and lighting systems manufactured, marketed and used in Egypt

The level of compliance of the targeted appliances with the adopted minimum energy performance standards (a priori the MEPS to be adopted in Egypt are expected to be in line with those adopted in EU.)

comment.narrative: From 10% to 50% higher energy consumption (depending on the appliance) when comparing to the planned MEPS (for further details see Annex 7-4).

Over 80% of the appliances sold in the Egyptian market are in compliance with the requirements of those MEPS and labeling schemes that are expected to be in force by the end of the project (for further details see Annex 7-5).

The Ministry of Electricity and Renewable Energy has launched a National initiative for disseminating LED lamps to the residential sector. The Ministry contracted a supplier to provide 13 million LED lamps with different wattage (4,6,9 watt) to be sold on installments added to electricity bills. The project provided the Ministry with the technical specifications and testing procedures for tendering purposes.
To date, more than 1.8 Million lamps have been sold via Electricity Distribution Companies, thus achieving an estimated saving of 40 Million KWh for the 3 month period from the starting selling date up to 30/06/2015.
Different government entities are working on reducing electricity consumption as per the Cabinet instructions for all government buildings to reduce electricity consumption by 20%.
The Ministry of Electricity and Renewable Energy signed a protocol of cooperation with the Ministry of Local Development and the Arab Organization for Industrialization for LE 2.3 billion to increase efficiency of street lighting systems to replace the 400 watt and 250 sodium lamps by high efficient 150 and 100 watt sodium lamps respectively. The total number of lamps has been estimated at 4 million lamps and the project duration is expected to be around 3 years. The first stage is for replacing 0.5 million lamps, up till now 150000, 400 watt lamps have been replaced by 150 watt. In the mean time, the previous program initiated by the Ministry of Electricity and Energy for increasing street lighting efficiency is still ongoing in some governorates but through their own resources with the assistance of the electricity distribution companies, this includes (CFLs 85-125 watt, replacing 100 and150 watt sodium lamps with electronic ballast). Meanwhile, The New Urban Communities Authority (NUCA) announced issuing a contract for LE 70 million to change all street lighting systems in the new cities to LED systems
Ministry of Tourism has announced an innovative lending program offering loans to hotels for replacing lighting systems and installing solar water heaters that will be settled based on the occupancy rate in the hotel
Ministry of Industry has released a Ministerial decree to activate MEPS for fans and dishwashers.
Egyptian Organization for Standardization (EOS) activated, in cooperation with other key relevant authorities, the new national S& L programme enforcement mechanism to confirm the compliance of the issued labels with the developed MEPS. These labels are released based on the testing results performed at NREA’s labs established in the first phase of the project.
Based on the results of the Energy Efficiency tests (NREA) and the issued labels from (EOS) ,Mmost of the released labels are rated either A or B except for the air conditioners which are rated C,D,E but still an improvement when compared to previous results showing a lower rate of compliance where some of the tested units were not complying with the MEPS.
Meanwhile the level of efficiency of these appliances have improved comparing to the last year levels
The awareness campaign that has been launched last year for increasing public awareness of energy efficiency through the young students will continue this year but on a larger scale to cover 10 of the Egyptian governorates through the cooperation with the NGOs working with the Small Grants Program of GEF and the Consumer Agency Protection.

description.narrative: Amount of reduced CO2 emissions compared to the projected baseline

comment.narrative: See the baseline scenario presented in Annex 7-4.

Direct incremental reduction of GHG emissions by 0.95 million tons of CO2eq by the end of the project and estimated cumulative indirect GHG emission reduction of at least 53 million tons of CO2eq by 2025 on the basis of a conservative policy scenario and a GEF causality factor of 60%.

The achieved energy savings from this reporting period have been estimated at 477,109 MWh equating to 0.257 MTons CO2 based on a grid emission factor of 0.54 tons of CO2/ MWh.
These savings are calculated for a three months period for the LED lighting program and the street lighting program which is the period starting from the selling date and date of starting of street lighting program up to end of June, while for the impact resulting from raising the set point of air conditioners from 16 degree centigrade to 21 degree centigrade the calculated savings are calculated for a 4 month period, the savings of the implemented efficient lighting pilot projects have been calculated based on the ending date of each project..
